svcproc.para: The flow charts in this section make reference to connector and circuit numbers for the 1000, 3600, 3700, 3800 and 4000FBC model families. For the 2000, 3900FC, 4000 and 8000 models, refer to the appropriate circuit diagram in this section for the corresponding circuit and connector numbers.

figure.caption: TEST 1 CHECKING BATTERY FEED/IGNITION FEED/GROUND CIRCUITS TO ECU

note.para: The flow charts in this section reference circuit and connector numbers for the 2000, 4000, and 8000 model families. For the 3600, 3800 and 3900FC series vehicles, refer to those circuit diagrams for the corresponding numbers.
This test must be performed with fully charged batteries. Tests for ignition and battery voltage in this test should be within 1.0 volts of battery voltage.
Resistance or voltage tests should not be performed into the ECU. Tests will be performed at the ECU harness connector. Use a digital multimeter, such as the Fluke 23, to perform tests.
Before performing this test, check all connectors and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage, loose terminals or wires and corrosion.

TEST 7 TEST FOR SPEEDOMETER SIGNAL FROM ECU

note.para: This test is performed with drive axles raised from the floor and vehicle safely supported by floor stands. Be sure to block wheels.

The flow charts in this section reference circuit and connector numbers for the 2000, 4000, and 8000 model families. For the 3600, 3800 and 3900FC series vehicles, refer to those circuit diagrams for the corresponding numbers.
This test must be performed with fully charged batteries. Tests for ignition and battery voltage in this test should be within 1.0 volts of battery voltage.
A digital AC Meter (Fluke 23) is used to measure the AC voltage output from the ECU.
The speedometer output from the ECU will range from 0.0 AC volts to approximately 5.0 AC volts
Resistance or voltage tests should not be performed into the ECU. Tests will be performed at the ECU harness connector. Use a digital multimeter, such as the Fluke 23, to perform tests.
Before performing this test, check all connectors and grounds for clean, tight connections free of damage, loose terminals or wires and corrosion.
